posts.title: React2Shell CVE-2025-55182
posts.description: Technical breakdown of CVE-2025-55182 (React2Shell), a critical remote code execution vulnerability affecting React Server Components and Next.js applications.
posts.summary: Critical RCE vulnerability in React & Next.js, nicknamed React2Shell, CVE-2025-55182.
posts.content:
React2Shell CVE-2025-55182

Explained: Critical RCE Vulnerability in React & Next.js.

Introduction

Modern web development just faced its Log4Shell moment. On December 3, 2025, a critical vulnerability in React Server Components (RSC) was publicly disclosed: CVE-2025-55182, nicknamed React2Shell. The flaw enables unauthenticated remote code execution (RCE) against servers running vulnerable React and Next.js applications, earning a CVSS score of 10.0 ‚Äî the highest possible severity.

This vulnerability allows attackers to execute arbitrary system commands using a single crafted HTTP request ‚Äî no authentication required.

Why This Is So Dangerous

React Server Components, introduced in React 19, allow portions of applications to render server-side for performance optimization. However, this architecture relies on streaming serialized payloads via the React Flight protocol.

The vulnerability stems from flawed deserialization logic, allowing malicious payloads to:

  • Manipulate JavaScript prototypes
  • Resolve dangerous Node.js modules such as child_process
  • Execute system-level commands on the host server

The vulnerable execution path centers around a function named requireModule().

Exploitation in the Wild

This vulnerability was exploited within hours of disclosure. Threat intelligence reports confirmed active exploitation by China-aligned groups including Earth Lamia and Jackpot Panda.

Observed Attack Activity

  • Credential harvesting by dumping .env files
  • Host reconnaissance using whoami, uname, and id
  • Persistence attempts via file writes to /tmp/

Public proof-of-concept exploits were released on GitHub within 24 hours, achieving near 100% success against default create-next-app installations.

Conclusion

CVE-2025-55182 represents a critical security failure in modern server-rendered React architectures. Immediate patching and endpoint hardening are essential to prevent full server compromise.
